data.title: Timberwolves: For Kevin Garnett, new team, lower numbers, same effort
data.meta_description: When Kevin Garnett returns to Target Center on Friday with the Brooklyn Nets, the 19-year NBA veteran will not share advice and wisdom with young Kevin Love on how best to lead the Timberwolves. “That is a relationship that doesn’t happen for KG for one reason,” said Troy Hudson, Garnett’s teammate in Minnesota from 2002 […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

When Kevin Garnett returns to Target Center on Friday with the Brooklyn Nets, the 19-year NBA veteran will not share advice and wisdom with young Kevin Love on how best to lead the Timberwolves.

“That is a relationship that doesn’t happen for KG for one reason,” said Troy Hudson, Garnett’s teammate in Minnesota from 2002 to 2007.

Loyalty, Hudson says, and the retired guard gives an example of how Garnett treated rookie center Dwight Howard during a 2005 game in Orlando.

“Dwight Howard tried to talk to KG on a friendly side,” Hudson recalled Thursday. “And KG looked at him and said a few of those KG choice words.

“After the game on the bus, I said, ‘KG, why are you so mean to the young fella?’ He said, ‘As long as I continue to play, that dude is looking for my job. The next guy is trying to be better than me, trying to destroy me when he sees me. For as long as I’m in this league, I’m not friends with anyone besides the 12 guys that are in this locker room.’ ”

Last offseason, Garnett’s locker room changed for the second time in his career, with a trade from the Boston Celtics to the Nets. In the first 11 games Garnett has been a shadow of his former MVP self.

Garnett, 37, has posted career-low averages in minutes (22.7), field-goal percentage (34), points (6.6) and assists (1.7). Those numbers pale in comparison with his MVP season of 2003-04, when he played nearly 40 minutes a game for the Wolves, shot just shy of 50 percent from the field and set career highs in points (24.2), rebounds (13.9) and blocks (2.2).

“He was an absolute monster that year,” said Fred Hoiberg, Garnett’s teammate in 2003-04 and 2004-05.

Despite the numbers, Hudson and Hoiberg said Garnett’s value to the Nets remains high. Mainly, it’s leadership and experience, with a championship ring earned with Boston in 2008.

“He leads two ways,” said Hoiberg, the men’s basketball coach at Iowa State. “He is a great leader because he leads by example, and he is vocal, as well.”

The Nets, with the NBA’s highest payroll, are 3-8, having lost their three past games. With a first-year coach in Jason Kidd; new players in Garnett, Paul Pierce and Jason Terry; and an injury to guard Deron Williams, Brooklyn is still trying to jell.

Garnett won’t stop working toward that goal, Hoiberg said.

“It was always amazing to me,” he said of Garnett’s work ethic. “Kevin would play in back-to-back games (in 2003-04), where he would play 45 minutes a game and then he would be the first guy in the gym the next morning — whether he was in there shooting or in the weight room. Again, when you see a guy like that, there is a reason that you are an MVP candidate each and every year. It’s because of the way he works.”

Garnett never has lost in the seven games he has played against the Wolves, the team that drafted him out of high school with the fifth pick in the 1995 draft. In those games since 2007, Garnet has averaged 14.9 points and 10.3 rebounds.

When he returns to Target Center for the fourth time as a visitor, the Wolves expect a brisk number of walk-up sales but no sellout, said Brad Ruiter, vice president of communications.

Garnett never wanted to leave Target Center, Hudson said.

“Even though he knew it was going to be three or four years of rebuilding, he was still prepared to be here and be in the trenches with the Timberwolves during that time,” Hudson said.

Garnett was again reluctant to be traded last offseason, according to a Sports Illustrated story. In the piece, Pierce said Garnett was close to retirement, but he was able to sell Garnett on Brooklyn.

“A lot of players these days, the first sign that they can go to another team to win a championship, they are out,” Hudson said.

But not Garnett, Hudson said: “He is just a throwback player.”

Originally Published: November 20, 2013 at 11:01 p.m.
